Business.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Business section of the META company report:

• Meta's mission is to build the future of human connection and technology that makes it possible.
• The company generates substantially all of its revenue from selling advertising placements on its family of apps to marketers, which accounts for 79% of total costs and expenses in 2024.
• In 2024, Meta's Family of Apps (FoA) investments were $75.25 billion, including expenses related to headcount, data centers, and technical infrastructure.
• The company is investing heavily in its Reality Labs (RL) segment, with total RL investments of $19.88 billion in 2024, including expenses related to headcount and technology development.
• Meta expects the metaverse to become the next computing platform and a future of social interaction.
• The company plans to focus on several key investment areas in 2025, including generative AI, discovery engine, metaverse, wearables, Threads, monetization, platform integrity, community support, and infrastructure capacity.

Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Risk Factors section in bullet points:

* The company's business is subject to risks that may prevent it from achieving its objectives or adversely affect its financial condition, results of operations, cash flows, and prospects.
* The company faces risks related to its product offerings, including:
 + Loss of users and reduction in spending by marketers
 + Reduced availability of data signals for ad targeting and measurement tools
 + Failure of new products to attract or retain users or generate revenue
* The company also faces risks related to its business operations and financial results, including:
 + Fluctuations in financial results
 + Unfavorable media coverage affecting brand reputation
 + Disruptions in service due to technical issues or catastrophic events
* The company is subject to government regulation and enforcement, including:
 + Restrictions on access to Facebook products in certain countries
 + Compliance with evolving laws and regulations related to data protection, advertising, and competition
* The company faces risks related to data security, platform integrity, and intellectual property, including:
 + Security breaches and cyber incidents
 + Unauthorized access or disclosure of user data
 + Intellectual property rights infringement
* The company's Class A common stock is subject to limitations on its holders' ability to influence corporate matters due to the dual class structure.

Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Cybersecurity section of Meta's document, formatted as bullet points:

• Meta experiences cybersecurity incidents of varying degrees due to its prominence and scale.
• The company collects, stores, processes, and transmits a large amount of personal data and content on its systems.
• Meta has an information security program with policies and controls designed to mitigate cybersecurity risk.
• The company uses a risk management framework based on applicable laws and regulations, industry standards, and industry-recognized practices.
• Meta regularly conducts risk assessments to evaluate the maturity and effectiveness of its systems and processes in addressing cybersecurity threats.
• The company engages third-party security experts and consultants to assist with assessment and enhancement of its cybersecurity risk management processes.
• Meta maintains a privacy risk management program to assess privacy risks related to user data collection, use, sharing, and storage.
• The company provides annual cybersecurity and privacy training for all employees.
• Meta has a specific policy and practice governing third-party security risks, including a third-party assessment (TPA) process.

Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Properties section in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, META owned and leased approximately 11 million square feet of office and building space for its corporate headquarters.
• Approximately two million square feet of unoccupied office and building space was planned to be subleased, early terminated, or abandoned related to facilities consolidation restructuring efforts.
• META owns 27 data center locations globally.
• The company has offices in more than 90 cities across North America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia-Pacific, and Latin America.

Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Legal Proceedings section in bullet points:

• META is subject to numerous claims, litigation, regulatory, tax, and government inquiries and investigations in jurisdictions around the world.
• The company may not be successful in defending these matters and may incur substantial costs if they are resolved adversely or result in unfavorable judgments.
• META has experienced outcomes with negative publicity and reputational harm, diverting resources and management's time from their business.
• The number and potential significance of litigation and investigations involving the company have increased over the last several years.
• The company is facing numerous cases in the United States related to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, including products liability theories that have survived motions to dismiss.
• META is subject to new regulatory regimes outside of the United States, including the Digital Services Act and similar statutes in non-EU countries.
• The company is facing inquiries and investigations regarding regulatory compliance, as well as private litigation in Europe claiming damages and/or injunctions for alleged failings to comply with such requirements.
• META's potential exposure to substantial damages awards and fines has increased due to the growth of its users and revenue.

Market for Registrant's Common Equity, R.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities section:

• As of December 31, 2024, there were 2,931 stockholders of record of Meta Platforms' Class A common stock.
• The closing price of Meta Platforms' Class A common stock was $585.51 per share as reported on the Nasdaq Global Select Market.
• There were 24 stockholders of record of Meta Platforms' Class B common stock as of December 31, 2024.
• In February 2024, Meta Platforms declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.50 per share to holders of its Class A and Class B common stock.
• Total dividend and dividend equivalent payments for the year ended December 31, 2024, were $4.38 billion for Class A common stock and $691 million for Class B common stock.
• Meta Platforms had no share repurchase activity for the three months ended December 31, 2024.

Management's Discussion and Analysis of.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations section in bullet points:

* Total revenue for 2024 was $164.50 billion, an increase of 22% compared to 2023.
* Revenue on a constant currency basis would have increased 23% compared to 2023.
* Ad impressions delivered across the Family of Apps in 2024 increased 11% year-over-year.
* Average price per ad increased 10% year-over-year.
* Income from operations for 2024 was $69.38 billion, an increase of $22.63 billion, or 48%, compared to 2023.
* The increase in costs and expenses was mainly due to increases in operational expenses related to data centers and technical infrastructure and employee compensation.

We calculate our revenue by user geograp.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II in bullet points:

* The revenue of META is calculated by user geography based on estimates of where ad impressions are delivered, virtual and digital goods are purchased, or consumer hardware products are shipped.
* Revenue in regions such as United States & Canada and Europe is relatively higher due to the size and maturity of those online and mobile advertising markets.
* Ad impression growth is primarily in geographies that monetize at lower rates, such as Asia-Pacific and Rest of World.
* In 2024:
 + Revenue increased by 18% in United States & Canada relative to 2023.
 + Revenue increased by 26% in Europe relative to 2023.
 + Revenue increased by 22% in Asia-Pacific relative to 2023.
 + Revenue increased by 31% in Rest of World relative to 2023.

We define a daily active person as a reg.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II:

* The daily active person (DAP) is defined as a registered and logged-in user of Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and/or WhatsApp who visited at least one product through a mobile device application or web browser on a given day.
* Worldwide DAP increased 5% to 3.35 billion on average during December 2024 from 3.19 billion during December 2023.
* The error margin for DAP estimates is approximately 3% of the worldwide DAP, although this may vary significantly due to difficulties in attributing multiple user accounts to individual people.
* Our Family of Apps (FoA) revenue represents the substantial majority of our total revenue.
* The annual worldwide ARPP in 2024 was $49.63, an increase of 15% from 2023.
* Ad impressions grew by 10% year-over-year, while average price per ad increased by 20%.
* Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with GAAP and require estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, costs, and expenses.

Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk section in bullet points:

• Foreign currency exchange net losses were $690 million, $366 million, and $81 million recognized in 2024, 2023, and 2022, respectively.

• A hypothetical 100 basis point increase in market interest rates would have resulted in a decrease of $680 million and $355 million in the market value of available-for-sale debt securities and cash equivalents as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.

• As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the aggregate principal amounts of fixed-rate senior notes outstanding were $29.0 billion and $18.50 billion, respectively.

• Marketable equity securities represent $1.23 billion of investments as of December 31, 2024.

• A hypothetical adverse price change of 10% on our December 31, 2024 balance would decrease the fair value of marketable equity securities by $123 million.

• The company has not entered into derivatives or other financial instruments to hedge foreign currency exchange risk, but may do so in the future.

Financial Statements and Supplementary D.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• The consolidated balance sheets of Meta Platforms, Inc. (the Company) were audited by Ernst & Young LLP as of December 31, 2024.
• The related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years ended December 31, 2024, were also audited.
• The auditor expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024.
• The audit was conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB).
• The auditor served as the Company's auditor since 2007.

Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Controls and Procedures section, formatted as bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, META's disclosure controls and procedures are designed at a reasonable assurance level.
• The CEO and CFO have concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures are effective to provide reasonable assurance that required information is recorded, processed, and reported in a timely manner.
• Our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2024, based on the assessment conducted by management.
• There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting identified during the fourth quarter of 2024 that materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect it.

Other Information.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Other Information section:

• Peggy Alford, a member of our board of directors, entered into a trading plan that provides for the sale of an aggregate of up to $1.2 million worth of shares of our Class A common stock.
• The plan will terminate on November 15, 2025, subject to early termination for certain specified events set forth in the plan.
• Christopher K. Cox, our Chief Product Officer, entered into a trading plan that provides for the sale of an aggregate of up to 60,000 shares of our Class A common stock.
• The plan will terminate on February 20, 2026, subject to early termination for certain specified events set forth in the plan.

Form 10-K Summary.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART IV - Form 10-K Summary section in bullet points:

• The Registrant (META) has filed its Annual Report on Form 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
• The report was signed by Susan Li and Katherine R. Kelly, who serve as attorneys-in-fact for John Elkann, Charles Songhurst, and Dana White, who did not sign the report due to their recent election to the board of directors effective December 30, 2024.
• The report was filed on January 29, 2025.
• The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires the filing of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
